39287944.P: Participants from two randomized clinical trials, TheraP (n = 200) and VISION (n = 831), with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.
39287944.I: Lutetium Lu 177 prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) treatment.
39287944.C: Cabazitaxel in TheraP and physician's choice of protocol-permitted treatments (PPT) in VISION.
39287944.O: Improved overall survival (OS) observed in the cabazitaxel group in TheraP compared to VISION; no significant differences in OS between Lu-177 PSMA and cabazitaxel after controlling for crossover.

39166959.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) who have progressed on androgen receptor-axis-targeted (ARAT) therapies.
39166959.I: Various interventions including ARAT-based therapies, taxane-based treatments, PARP inhibitors, immunotherapies, and other therapies.
39166959.O: Limited effective treatment options identified; taxane-based chemotherapy and radionuclide therapy provided the most value.

38726840.P: Patients with liposarcoma (LPS), a subtype of soft tissue sarcoma.
38726840.I: Targeted therapies and new treatment options based on molecular biology and genomic profiling.
38726840.O: Highlighting promising ongoing and published clinical trials regarding targeted therapies in LPSs.

38683200.P: 192 men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.
38683200.I: Risk-adapted combinations of androgen signaling inhibitors including abiraterone acetate, prednisone, apalutamide, and carboplatin + cabazitaxel.
38683200.O: Median overall survival varied by treatment module; adding ipilimumab did not improve outcomes.

38663168.P: Patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) or luminal B/HER2-negative breast cancer, specifically those with cT2-3, any cN or cT1, cN+/pN(SLN)+.
38663168.I: Neoadjuvant treatment with cabazitaxel versus paclitaxel.
38663168.O: No significant differences in invasive disease-free survival (iDFS), distant disease-free survival (DDFS), or overall survival (OS) between cabazitaxel and paclitaxel after long-term follow-up.

38378399.P: Men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer progressing after docetaxel.
38378399.O: Overall survival was similar between the two groups, with median overall survival of 19.1 months for [(177)Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 and 19.6 months for cabazitaxel.

38043558.P: Men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer progressing after docetaxel.
38043558.O: Overall survival was similar between the two groups, with median overall survival of 19.1 months for [(177)Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 and 19.6 months for cabazitaxel.

37582240.P: Men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC).
37582240.O: AAP + C showed improved radiographic progression-free survival (14.8 months) and overall survival (24.5 months) compared to AAP alone (6.4 months rPFS and 18.3 months OS).

37439809.P: Patients with clinically localized, D'Amico high-risk prostate cancer.
37439809.I: Neoadjuvant abiraterone acetate and leuprolide acetate with cabazitaxel.
37439809.C: Neoadjuvant abiraterone acetate and leuprolide acetate without cabazitaxel.
37439809.O: No significant difference in pathologic complete response/minimal residual disease between the two arms (43.2% vs. 45.5%).

36917691.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC).
36917691.C: Conventional dosing of cabazitaxel at 25 mg/m2.
36917691.O: Pharmacokinetic-guided dosing improved median overall survival (16.2 months vs. 7.3 months) and progression-free survival (9.5 months vs. 4.4 months) compared to conventional dosing.

36753698.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) who had nonprogressive disease after taxane treatment.
36753698.O: Significantly improved radiographic progression-free survival (rPFS) at 12 weeks, median rPFS of 5.5 months on darolutamide vs 4.5 months on placebo, and improved PSA 50% response rate (22% vs 4%).

36692012.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC).
36692012.I: Combination therapies including AKT inhibitors or PARP inhibitors with abiraterone, and olaparib for patients with BRCA1, BRCA2, or ATM alterations.
36692012.O: Improved oncologic outcomes such as radiographical progression-free survival, but no overall survival improvement in first-line settings.

36407784.P: Asian patients with advanced/metastatic prostate cancer, including nonmetastatic castration-resistant PC, metastatic castration-sensitive PC, and metastatic castration-resistant PC.
36407784.I: Various therapies including abiraterone acetate plus prednisone, enzalutamide, lutetium-177 PSMA, docetaxel, apalutamide, radium-223, darolutamide, and cabazitaxel.
36407784.O: Clinical benefits of several treatments in terms of overall, disease-free, and metastasis-free survival, with good tolerability and no new safety signals identified.

36261050.P: Men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer after treatment with docetaxel.
36261050.O: Higher PSA response rate for [(177)Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 compared to cabazitaxel, with PSMA-PET SUVmean predictive of response.

36194950.I: Three-weekly cabazitaxel (25 mg/m²) or weekly paclitaxel (80 mg/m²).
36194950.O: No significant difference in median progression-free survival or overall survival, but cabazitaxel had a lower risk of peripheral neuropathy and better quality of life outcomes.

36126602.P: Patients with recurrent head and neck cancer
36126602.I: Cabazitaxel as second-line or above therapy
36126602.C: Docetaxel as second-line or above therapy

35039605.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) who received prior docetaxel and progressed on alternative androgen-receptor-targeted agents
35039605.O: Comparison of characteristics and treatment patterns with the CARD population; similar duration of response to cabazitaxel in real-world data

34789394.P: Chemotherapy-naive men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC)
34789394.I: Docetaxel followed by cabazitaxel or vice versa
34789394.O: Patient preference for cabazitaxel over docetaxel due to less fatigue and better quality of life

34450475.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) previously treated with docetaxel and alternative androgen-receptor-targeted agents
34450475.O: High baseline neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio predicts poor outcomes with ARTA; cabazitaxel's efficacy is retained irrespective of NLR

34405748.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC)
34405748.O: Improved prostate-specific antigen response rate and fewer grade 3/4 adverse events compared to cabazitaxel

34274136.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC), including 135 patients aged ≥70 years (median age 76 years) and younger patients.
34274136.I: Cabazitaxel (25 mg/m² plus prednisone and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor).
34274136.C: Abiraterone (1000 mg plus prednisone) or enzalutamide (160 mg).
34274136.O: Cabazitaxel significantly improved median radiographic progression-free survival (rPFS) and overall survival (OS) compared to abiraterone/enzalutamide in both older and younger patients.

34103179.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) participating in two prospective phase 3 trials (FIRSTANA and PROSELICA).
34103179.I: Low-pass whole-genome sequencing (lpWGS) of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA).
34103179.O: Plasma tumor fraction was prognostic for overall survival and provided added value compared to existing biomarkers; longitudinal changes were associated with drug response.

34028551.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC).
34028551.O: Comparative effectiveness research comparing survival endpoints and response rates between olaparib and cabazitaxel.

33836265.P: Patients with androgen receptor pathway inhibitor (ARPI)-naive metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) and poor prognosis features.
33836265.C: Physician's choice of enzalutamide or abiraterone plus prednisone.
33836265.O: Cabazitaxel was associated with a higher clinical benefit rate (80% vs 62%) and had a median overall survival of 37.0 months compared to 15.5 months for the comparator group.

33625671.O: Guidelines for the treatment of advanced prostate cancer, emphasizing the importance of molecular research and new drug development.

33581798.P: Men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer, requiring cabazitaxel as the next appropriate standard treatment, with adequate renal, haematological, and liver function, and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0-2.
33581798.I: Lutetium-177 [(177)Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 administered intravenously every 6 weeks for up to six cycles.
33581798.C: Cabazitaxel administered intravenously every 3 weeks for up to ten cycles.
33581798.O: Higher prostate-specific antigen (PSA) response in the [(177)Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 group (66%) compared to the cabazitaxel group (37%), and fewer grade 3-4 adverse events in the [(177)Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 group (33%) compared to the cabazitaxel group (53%).

32968994.P: Patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) who were previously treated with docetaxel and an anti-androgen receptor therapy (ARTA).
32968994.O: Significant efficacy benefits in favor of cabazitaxel compared to a second ARTA therapy.

32926841.P: Patients aged ≥18 years with confirmed metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer, Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status ≤2, previously treated with docetaxel and an alternative androgen signalling-targeted inhibitor.
32926841.I: Cabazitaxel (25 mg/m² intravenously every 3 weeks) plus prednisone and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor.
32926841.O: Improved pain response, time to pain progression, and quality of life (EQ-5D-5L utility index) with cabazitaxel compared to abiraterone or enzalutamide.

32878814.P: Twenty-six patients with chemotherapy-resistant epithelial ovarian cancer, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer.
32878814.I: Cabazitaxel at a dose of 25 mg/m² (on day 1 of each 3-week cycle).
32878814.O: 54% of patients were alive and without progression after 3 months; response rate was 46% according to CA125 criteria.

32380503.P: Patients with metastatic prostate cancer who initially responded to docetaxel and maintained a minimum progression-free interval of 3-6 months.
32380503.O: Potential effectiveness of docetaxel rechallenge in patients who initially responded to docetaxel.
